 009: ################################################
 010: ##            GLOBAL DEFINITIONS              ##
 011: ################################################
 012: 
 013: ####  Butcher's tableau coefficients   ####
 014: 
 015: # These coefficients are needed for the RK45 Solver to work. 
 016: # When calculating the different samples for the derivative, each
 017: # sample is weighted differently according to some coefficients: These
 018: # numbers the weighting coefficients. Each Runge-Kutta method has its
 019: # coefficients, which in turns define the method completely and these
 020: # are the coefficients of Dopri5, an adaptative RK45 schema.
 021: 
 022: # For more information on this matter:
 023: 
 024: # https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Runge%E2%80%93Kutta_methods
 025:

 068: 
 069: 
 070: #### System Size ####
 071: 
 072: # We are not constructing a general-pourpose integrator, instead we knoe that we
 073: # want to integrate Kerr's geodesics. The system of differential equations for
 074: # our version of the geodesic equations ( our version <-> the Hamiltonian we are
 075: # using ) has 5 equations: 3 for the coordinates and 2 for the momenta because
 076: # the third momenta equation vanishes explicitly. 
 077:

 153:     # Get canonical momenta
 154: 
+155:     cdef double ro = sqrt(r2 + a2 * cos(theta)**2)

+156:     cdef double delta = r2 - 2*r + a2
  __pyx_v_delta = ((__pyx_v_r2 - (2.0 * __pyx_v_r)) + __pyx_v_a2);

+157:     cdef double sigma = sqrt((r2 + a2)**2 - a2 * delta * sin(theta)**2)
  __pyx_v_sigma = sqrt((pow((__pyx_v_r2 + __pyx_v_a2), 2.0) - ((__pyx_v_a2 * __pyx_v_delta) * pow(sin(__pyx_v_theta), 2.0))));

+158:     cdef double pomega = sigma * sin(theta) / ro
  __pyx_v_pomega = ((__pyx_v_sigma * sin(__pyx_v_theta)) / __pyx_v_ro);

 159: 
 160:     # Compute energy as measured by the FIDO. See (A.11)
 161: 
 162:     # TODO: Fix this mess

 166: 
 167:     # Compute the canonical momenta. See (A.11)
+168:     cdef double pR = E * ro * nR / sqrt(delta)

+169:     cdef double pTheta = E * ro * nTheta

+170:     cdef double pPhi = E * pomega * nPhi

 174:     # Set conserved quantities. See (A.12)
+175:     cdef double b = pPhi

+176:     cdef double q = pTheta**2 + cos(theta)**2*(b**2 / sin(theta)**2 - a2)

+209:     cdef double sigma = sqrt((r2 + a2)**2 - a2 * delta * sin(theta)**2)

+211:     cdef double omega = 2 * a * r / ( sigma * sigma )

    __pyx_v_result = (__pyx_v_result * __pyx_v_alpha);

+229:         result /= ro * pomega
    __pyx_v_result = (__pyx_v_result / (__pyx_v_ro * __pyx_v_pomega));

+230:         result -=  pphi * omega
    __pyx_v_result = (__pyx_v_result - (__pyx_v_pphi * __pyx_v_omega));

 231: 
+232:         return result
    __pyx_r = __pyx_v_result;
    goto __pyx_L0;
  }

 251:                  double [:] initCond,double[:] data,
 252:                  double [:,:] result):
 253:     """
 254:     This function acts as an interface with the RK45 Solver. Its pourpose is avoid the
 255:     overhead of calling the Runge-Kutta solver multiple times from python, which creates
 256:     and unpacks a lot of python objects. The caller must pass a result buffer ( a python
 257:     memoryview) and this function will populate the buffer with the result of successive
 258:     calls to the Runge-Kutta solver.
 259: 
 260:     :param x: double
 261:         The initial point of the independent variable for the integration
 262:     :param xend: double
 263:         The ending point of the independent variable for the integration.
 264:     :param n_steps: int
 265:         The number of steps to make when performing the integration.
 266:         ¡IMPORTANT! This number has to be larger than the dimension of the `result` buffer.
 267:     :param initCond: memoryview
 268:         The initial conditions at the point x.
 269:         ¡IMPORTANT! The content of this memoryview will be overwritten by the solver.
 270:     :param data: memoryview
 271:         Aditional data needed for computing the right hand side of the equations to integrate.
 272:     :param result: memoryview (2D)
 273:         A buffer to store the result of the integration in each RK45 step.
 274:         ¡IMPORTANT! The first dimension of the buffer must be larger or equal than n_steps.
 275:     """
+276:     cdef double hOrig = 0.01
  __pyx_v_hOrig = 0.01;

+277:     cdef double globalFacold = 1.0e-4
  __pyx_v_globalFacold = 1.0e-4;

+278:     cdef double step = (xend - x) / n_steps
  __pyx_v_step = ((__pyx_v_xend - __pyx_v_x) / ((double)__pyx_v_n_steps));

 279:     cdef int current_step, i
 280: 
 281: 
 282:     # Create arrays to use in the solver and copy the initial conditions and
 283:     # data to them. This may seem a bit odd but is here because the function KerrGeodesicEquations
 284:     # is called with the initial data to compute K1 and with the calculated data to compute K2,...,Kn.
 285:     # As the type of the initCond variable is a memoryview we would need to use another memoryview to
 286:     # match the signature of the function but to do this we would need to allocate memory in the heap
 287:     # and we do NOT want to do this. So we use arrays of known size ( 5 ) and therefore we cannot use the
 288:     # memoryview that this function recieves. So we create ONCE two arrays and copy the data into them.
 289:     # Notice that this is done ONCE in contrast to the option of doing whatever alternative in the RK45Solver
 290:     # that will be called n_steps times, so the overhead is minimum with this option.
 291: 
 292:     cdef double initial_conditions[5]
 293:     cdef double aditional_data[4]
 294: 
+295:     for i in range(5): # TODO: SYSTEM_SIZE
  for (__pyx_t_1 = 0; __pyx_t_1 < 5; __pyx_t_1+=1) {
    __pyx_v_i = __pyx_t_1;

+296:         initial_conditions[i] = initCond[i]
    __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_v_i;
    (__pyx_v_initial_conditions[__pyx_v_i]) = (*((double *) ( /* dim=0 */ (__pyx_v_initCond.data + __pyx_t_2 * __pyx_v_initCond.strides[0]) )));
  }

 297: 
+298:     for i in range(4):
  for (__pyx_t_1 = 0; __pyx_t_1 < 4; __pyx_t_1+=1) {
    __pyx_v_i = __pyx_t_1;

+299:         aditional_data[i] = data[i]
    __pyx_t_3 = __pyx_v_i;
    (__pyx_v_aditional_data[__pyx_v_i]) = (*((double *) ( /* dim=0 */ (__pyx_v_data.data + __pyx_t_3 * __pyx_v_data.strides[0]) )));
  }

 300: 
 301:     # Store initial step conditions
 302: 
+303:     result[0,0] = initial_conditions[0]
  __pyx_t_4 = 0;
  __pyx_t_5 = 0;
  *((double *) ( /* dim=1 */ (( /* dim=0 */ (__pyx_v_result.data + __pyx_t_4 * __pyx_v_result.strides[0]) ) + __pyx_t_5 * __pyx_v_result.strides[1]) )) = (__pyx_v_initial_conditions[0]);

+304:     result[0,1] = initial_conditions[1]
  __pyx_t_6 = 0;
  __pyx_t_7 = 1;
  *((double *) ( /* dim=1 */ (( /* dim=0 */ (__pyx_v_result.data + __pyx_t_6 * __pyx_v_result.strides[0]) ) + __pyx_t_7 * __pyx_v_result.strides[1]) )) = (__pyx_v_initial_conditions[1]);

+305:     result[0,2] = initial_conditions[2]
  __pyx_t_8 = 0;
  __pyx_t_9 = 2;
  *((double *) ( /* dim=1 */ (( /* dim=0 */ (__pyx_v_result.data + __pyx_t_8 * __pyx_v_result.strides[0]) ) + __pyx_t_9 * __pyx_v_result.strides[1]) )) = (__pyx_v_initial_conditions[2]);

+306:     result[0,3] = initial_conditions[3]
  __pyx_t_10 = 0;
  __pyx_t_11 = 3;
  *((double *) ( /* dim=1 */ (( /* dim=0 */ (__pyx_v_result.data + __pyx_t_10 * __pyx_v_result.strides[0]) ) + __pyx_t_11 * __pyx_v_result.strides[1]) )) = (__pyx_v_initial_conditions[3]);

+307:     result[0,4] = initial_conditions[4]
  __pyx_t_12 = 0;
  __pyx_t_13 = 4;
  *((double *) ( /* dim=1 */ (( /* dim=0 */ (__pyx_v_result.data + __pyx_t_12 * __pyx_v_result.strides[0]) ) + __pyx_t_13 * __pyx_v_result.strides[1]) )) = (__pyx_v_initial_conditions[4]);

 308:

+310:     for current_step in range(n_steps):
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_n_steps;
  for (__pyx_t_14 = 0; __pyx_t_14 < __pyx_t_1; __pyx_t_14+=1) {
    __pyx_v_current_step = __pyx_t_14;

+311:         SolverRK45( initial_conditions, &x, x+step, &hOrig, 0.1, aditional_data, &globalFacold)
    __pyx_f_19geodesic_integrator_SolverRK45(__pyx_v_initial_conditions, (&__pyx_v_x), (__pyx_v_x + __pyx_v_step), (&__pyx_v_hOrig), 0.1, __pyx_v_aditional_data, (&__pyx_v_globalFacold), NULL);

 312: 
 313:         # Store the result of the integration in the buffer
 314: 
+315:         result[current_step + 1,0] = initial_conditions[0]

    __pyx_t_16 = 0;

+316:         result[current_step + 1,1] = initial_conditions[1]
    __pyx_t_17 = (__pyx_v_current_step + 1);
    __pyx_t_18 = 1;
    *((double *) ( /* dim=1 */ (( /* dim=0 */ (__pyx_v_result.data + __pyx_t_17 * __pyx_v_result.strides[0]) ) + __pyx_t_18 * __pyx_v_result.strides[1]) )) = (__pyx_v_initial_conditions[1]);

+317:         result[current_step + 1,2] = initial_conditions[2]
    __pyx_t_19 = (__pyx_v_current_step + 1);
    __pyx_t_20 = 2;
    *((double *) ( /* dim=1 */ (( /* dim=0 */ (__pyx_v_result.data + __pyx_t_19 * __pyx_v_result.strides[0]) ) + __pyx_t_20 * __pyx_v_result.strides[1]) )) = (__pyx_v_initial_conditions[2]);

+318:         result[current_step + 1,3] = initial_conditions[3]
    __pyx_t_21 = (__pyx_v_current_step + 1);
    __pyx_t_22 = 3;
    *((double *) ( /* dim=1 */ (( /* dim=0 */ (__pyx_v_result.data + __pyx_t_21 * __pyx_v_result.strides[0]) ) + __pyx_t_22 * __pyx_v_result.strides[1]) )) = (__pyx_v_initial_conditions[3]);

+319:         result[current_step + 1,4] = initial_conditions[4]
    __pyx_t_23 = (__pyx_v_current_step + 1);
    __pyx_t_24 = 4;
    *((double *) ( /* dim=1 */ (( /* dim=0 */ (__pyx_v_result.data + __pyx_t_23 * __pyx_v_result.strides[0]) ) + __pyx_t_24 * __pyx_v_result.strides[1]) )) = (__pyx_v_initial_conditions[4]);
  }

+325: cdef void KerrGeodesicEquations(double* y, double* f,double* data):
static void __pyx_f_19geodesic_integrator_KerrGeodesicEquations(double *__pyx_v_y, double *__pyx_v_f, double *__pyx_v_data) {
  double __pyx_v_r;
  double __pyx_v_r2;
  double __pyx_v_twor;
  double __pyx_v_theta;
  double __pyx_v_pR;
  double __pyx_v_pR2;
  double __pyx_v_pTheta;
  double __pyx_v_pTheta2;
  double __pyx_v_b;
  double __pyx_v_twob;
  double __pyx_v_b2;
  double __pyx_v_q;
  CYTHON_UNUSED double __pyx_v_bMinusA;
  double __pyx_v_bMinusAE;
  double __pyx_v_a;
  double __pyx_v_a2;
  double __pyx_v_sinT;
  double __pyx_v_cosT;
  double __pyx_v_sinT2;
  double __pyx_v_sinT2Inv;
  double __pyx_v_cosT2;
  double __pyx_v_P;
  double __pyx_v_R;
  double __pyx_v_D;
  double __pyx_v_Dinv;
  double __pyx_v_Z;
  double __pyx_v_DZplusR;
  double __pyx_v_rho2Inv;
  double __pyx_v_twoRho2Inv;
  double __pyx_v_rho4Inv;
  double __pyx_v_energy;
  double __pyx_v_energy2;
  double __pyx_v_dR;
  double __pyx_v_dZ;
  double __pyx_v_dRhoTimesRho;
  double __pyx_v_dD;
  double __pyx_v_sum1;
  double __pyx_v_sum2;
  double __pyx_v_sum3;
  double __pyx_v_sum4;
  double __pyx_v_sum5;
  double __pyx_v_sum6;
  double __pyx_v_cosT3;

  __Pyx_RefNannySetupContext("KerrGeodesicEquations", 0);

  /* function exit code */
  __Pyx_RefNannyFinishContext();
}

 326:     """
 327:     This function computes the right hand side of the Kerr geodesic equations described
 328:     in http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.03808.
 329: 
 330:     All the computations are highly optimized to avoid calculating the same term twice.
 331: 
 332:     :param y: pointer to double
 333:         The current coordinate values to compute the equations. ( Will not be modified)
 334:         The array must follow the following convention for the variables:
 335:             0 -> r
 336:             1 -> theta
 337:             2 -> phi
 338:             3 -> p_r
 339:             4 -> p_theta
 340: 
 341:     :param f: pointer to double
 342:         The place where the values of the equations will be stored.
 343:         The array will follow this convention:
 344:             0 -> d(r)/dt
 345:             1 -> d(theta)/dt
 346:             2 -> d(phi)/dt
 347:             3 -> d(p_r)/dt
 348:             4 -> d(p_theta)/dt
 349: 
 350:             Where t is the independent variable (propper time).
 351: 
 352:     :param data: pointer to double
 353:         Aditional data needed for the computation. Explicitly:
 354: 
 355:             0 -> b ( Angular momentum)
 356:             1 -> q ( Carter's constant)
 357:             2 -> a ( Black Hole spin)
 358:             3 -> e ( Energy )
 359:     """
 360:     # Variables to hold the position of the ray, its momenta and related
 361:     # operations between them and the constant a, which is the spin of the
 362:     # black hole.
 363:     cdef double r, r2, twor, theta, pR, pR2, pTheta, pTheta2, b, twob, b2, q, bMinusA, bMinusAE,a, a2
 364:     # Variables to hold the sine and cosine of theta, along with some
 365:     # operations with them
 366:     cdef double sinT, cosT, sinT2, sinT2Inv, cosT2
 367: 
 368:     # Variables to hold the value of the functions P, R, Delta (which is
 369:     # called D), Theta (which is called Z) and rho, along with some operations
 370:     # involving these values.
 371:     cdef double P, R, D, Dinv, Z, DZplusR, rho2Inv, twoRho2Inv, rho4Inv
 372: 
 373:     # Variable for the energy
 374: 
 375:     cdef double energy
 376:     cdef double energy2
 377: 
 378:     # Retrieval of the input data (position of the ray, momenta and
 379:     # constants).
+380:     r = y[0]
  __pyx_v_r = (__pyx_v_y[0]);

+381:     theta = y[1]
  __pyx_v_theta = (__pyx_v_y[1]);

+382:     pR = y[3]
  __pyx_v_pR = (__pyx_v_y[3]);

+383:     pTheta = y[4]
  __pyx_v_pTheta = (__pyx_v_y[4]);

 384: 
 385:     # Computation of the square of r, widely used in the computations.
+386:     r2 = r*r
  __pyx_v_r2 = (__pyx_v_r * __pyx_v_r);

 387: 
 388:     # Sine and cosine of theta, as well as their squares and inverses.
+389:     sinT = sin(theta)
  __pyx_v_sinT = sin(__pyx_v_theta);

+390:     cosT = cos(theta)
  __pyx_v_cosT = cos(__pyx_v_theta);

+391:     sinT2 = sinT*sinT
  __pyx_v_sinT2 = (__pyx_v_sinT * __pyx_v_sinT);

+392:     sinT2Inv = 1/sinT2
  __pyx_v_sinT2Inv = (1.0 / __pyx_v_sinT2);

+393:     cosT2 = cosT*cosT
  __pyx_v_cosT2 = (__pyx_v_cosT * __pyx_v_cosT);

 394: 
 395:     # Retrieval of the constants data: b and q, along with the computation of
 396:     # the square of b and the number b - a, repeateadly used throughout the
 397:     # computation
+398:     b = data[0]
  __pyx_v_b = (__pyx_v_data[0]);

+399:     q = data[1]
  __pyx_v_q = (__pyx_v_data[1]);

+400:     a = data[2]
  __pyx_v_a = (__pyx_v_data[2]);

+401:     energy = data[3]
  __pyx_v_energy = (__pyx_v_data[3]);

+402:     energy2 = energy * energy
  __pyx_v_energy2 = (__pyx_v_energy * __pyx_v_energy);

 403: 
+404:     a2 = a*a
  __pyx_v_a2 = (__pyx_v_a * __pyx_v_a);

+405:     b2 = b*b
  __pyx_v_b2 = (__pyx_v_b * __pyx_v_b);

+406:     bMinusA = b - a
  __pyx_v_bMinusA = (__pyx_v_b - __pyx_v_a);

+407:     bMinusAE = b - a * energy
  __pyx_v_bMinusAE = (__pyx_v_b - (__pyx_v_a * __pyx_v_energy));

 408: 
 409:     # Commonly used variables: R, D, Theta (that is called Z) and
 410:     # rho (and its square and cube).
+411:     D = r2 - 2*r + a2
  __pyx_v_D = ((__pyx_v_r2 - (2.0 * __pyx_v_r)) + __pyx_v_a2);

+412:     Dinv = 1/D
  __pyx_v_Dinv = (1.0 / __pyx_v_D);

 413: 
+414:     P = ( a2 + r2 ) * energy - a * b
  __pyx_v_P = (((__pyx_v_a2 + __pyx_v_r2) * __pyx_v_energy) - (__pyx_v_a * __pyx_v_b));

+415:     R = P*P - D*(bMinusAE*bMinusAE + q )
  __pyx_v_R = ((__pyx_v_P * __pyx_v_P) - (__pyx_v_D * ((__pyx_v_bMinusAE * __pyx_v_bMinusAE) + __pyx_v_q)));

+416:     Z = q - cosT2*(b2*sinT2Inv - energy2 *  a2)
  __pyx_v_Z = (__pyx_v_q - (__pyx_v_cosT2 * ((__pyx_v_b2 * __pyx_v_sinT2Inv) - (__pyx_v_energy2 * __pyx_v_a2))));

 417: 
+418:     rho2Inv = 1/(r2 + a2*cosT2)
  __pyx_v_rho2Inv = (1.0 / (__pyx_v_r2 + (__pyx_v_a2 * __pyx_v_cosT2)));

+419:     twoRho2Inv = rho2Inv/2
  __pyx_v_twoRho2Inv = (__pyx_v_rho2Inv / 2.0);

+420:     rho4Inv = rho2Inv*rho2Inv
  __pyx_v_rho4Inv = (__pyx_v_rho2Inv * __pyx_v_rho2Inv);

 421: 
 422:     # Squares of the momenta components
+423:     pR2 = pR*pR
  __pyx_v_pR2 = (__pyx_v_pR * __pyx_v_pR);

+424:     pTheta2 = pTheta*pTheta
  __pyx_v_pTheta2 = (__pyx_v_pTheta * __pyx_v_pTheta);

 425: 
 426:     # Double b and double r, that's it! :)
+427:     twob = 2*b
  __pyx_v_twob = (2.0 * __pyx_v_b);

+428:     twor = 2*r
  __pyx_v_twor = (2.0 * __pyx_v_r);

 429: 
 430:     # Declaration of variables used in the actual computation: dR, dZ, dRho
 431:     # and dD will store the derivatives of the corresponding functions (with
 432:     # respect to the corresponding variable in each thread). The sumX values
 433:     # are used as intermediate steps in the final computations, in order to
 434:     # ease notation.
 435:     cdef double dR, dZ, dRhoTimesRho, dD, sum1, sum2, sum3, sum4, sum5, sum6
 436: 
 437:     # *********************** EQUATION 1 *********************** //
+438:     f[0] = D * pR * rho2Inv
  (__pyx_v_f[0]) = ((__pyx_v_D * __pyx_v_pR) * __pyx_v_rho2Inv);

 439: 
 440:     # *********************** EQUATION 2 *********************** //
+441:     f[1] = pTheta * rho2Inv
  (__pyx_v_f[1]) = (__pyx_v_pTheta * __pyx_v_rho2Inv);

 442: 
 443:     # *********************** EQUATION 3 *********************** //
 444:     # Derivatives with respect to b
+445:     dR = -2.0 * D * bMinusAE + (-2.0) * a * P
  __pyx_v_dR = (((-2.0 * __pyx_v_D) * __pyx_v_bMinusAE) + ((-2.0 * __pyx_v_a) * __pyx_v_P));

+446:     dZ = - twob * cosT2 * sinT2Inv
  __pyx_v_dZ = (((-__pyx_v_twob) * __pyx_v_cosT2) * __pyx_v_sinT2Inv);

 447: 
+448:     f[2] = - (dR + D*dZ)*Dinv*twoRho2Inv
  (__pyx_v_f[2]) = (((-(__pyx_v_dR + (__pyx_v_D * __pyx_v_dZ))) * __pyx_v_Dinv) * __pyx_v_twoRho2Inv);

 449: 
 450:     # *********************** EQUATION 4 *********************** //
 451:     # Derivatives with respect to r
+452:     dD = twor - 2
  __pyx_v_dD = (__pyx_v_twor - 2.0);

+453:     dR = 4.0 * r * energy * P  - ( q + bMinusAE * bMinusAE ) * ( twor - 2.0 )
  __pyx_v_dR = ((((4.0 * __pyx_v_r) * __pyx_v_energy) * __pyx_v_P) - ((__pyx_v_q + (__pyx_v_bMinusAE * __pyx_v_bMinusAE)) * (__pyx_v_twor - 2.0)));

+454:     DZplusR = D*Z + R
  __pyx_v_DZplusR = ((__pyx_v_D * __pyx_v_Z) + __pyx_v_R);

 455: 
+456:     sum1 = + pTheta2
  __pyx_v_sum1 = __pyx_v_pTheta2;

+457:     sum2 = + D*pR2
  __pyx_v_sum2 = (__pyx_v_D * __pyx_v_pR2);

+458:     sum3 = - (DZplusR * Dinv)
  __pyx_v_sum3 = (-(__pyx_v_DZplusR * __pyx_v_Dinv));

+459:     sum4 = - (dD*pR2)
  __pyx_v_sum4 = (-(__pyx_v_dD * __pyx_v_pR2));

+460:     sum5 = + (dD*Z + dR) * Dinv
  __pyx_v_sum5 = (((__pyx_v_dD * __pyx_v_Z) + __pyx_v_dR) * __pyx_v_Dinv);

+461:     sum6 = - (dD*DZplusR * Dinv * Dinv)
  __pyx_v_sum6 = (-(((__pyx_v_dD * __pyx_v_DZplusR) * __pyx_v_Dinv) * __pyx_v_Dinv));

 462: 
+463:     f[3] = r*(sum1 + sum2 + sum3)*rho4Inv + (sum4 + sum5 + sum6)*twoRho2Inv

 500:     """
 501:      /**
 502:       * Applies the DOPRI5 algorithm over the system defined in the KerrGeodesicEquations
 503:       * function, using the initial conditions specified in InitCond,
 504:       * and returning the solution found at xend.
 505:       * @param[in,out]  Real*  globalX0     Start of the integration interval
 506:       *                        [x_0, x_{end}]. At the output, this variable is set
 507:       *                        to the final time the solver reached.
 508:       * @param[in]      Real   xend         End of the integration interval
 509:       *                        [x_0, x_{end}].
 510:       * @param[in,out]  Real*  initCond     Device pointer to a serialized matrix of
 511:       *                        initial conditions; i.e., given a 2D matrix of R rows
 512:       *                        and C columns, where every entry is an n-tuple of
 513:       *                        initial conditions (y_0[0], y_0[1], ..., y_0[n-1]),
 514:       *                        the vector pointed by devInitCond contains R*C*n
 515:       *                        serialized entries, starting with the first row from
 516:       *                        left to right, then the second one in the same order
 517:       *                        and so on.
 518:       *                        The elements of vector pointed by initCond are
 519:       *                        replaced with the new computed values at the end of
 520:       *                        the algorithm; please, make sure you will not need
 521:       *                        them after calling this procedure.
 522:       * @param[in,out]  Real*  hOrig        Step size. This code controls
 523:       *                        automatically the step size, but this value is taken
 524:       *                        as a test for the first try; furthermore, the method
 525:       *                        returns the last computed value of h to let the user
 526:       *                        know the final state of the solver.
 527:       * @param[in]      Real   hmax         Value of the maximum step size allowed,
 528:       *                        usually defined as x_{end} - x_0, as we do not to
 529:       *                        exceed x_{end} in one iteration.
 530:       * @param[in]      Real*  data         Device pointer to a serialized matrix of
 531:       *                        additional data to be passed to computeComonent;
 532:       *                        currently, this is used to pass the constants b and q
 533:       *                        of each ray to the KerrGeodesicEquations method.
 534:       * @param[out]     int*   iterations   Output variable to know how many
 535:       *                        iterations were spent in the computation
 536:       * @param[in,out]  float* globalFacold Input and output variable, used as a
 537:       *                        first value for facold and to let the caller know the
 538:       *                        final value of facold.
 539:       */

 692:         # The Butcher's table (Table 5.2, [1]), shows that the estimated
 693:         # solution has exactly the same coefficients as the ones used to
 694:         # compute K7. Then, the solution is the last computed y1!
 695:

 697:         # between the solution y and the higher order solution \hat{y}, as
 698:         # specified in the last two rows of the Butcher's table (Table
 699:         # 5.2, [1]). Instead of computing \hat{y} and then substract it
 700:         # from y, the differences between the coefficientes of each
 701:         # solution have been computed and the error is directly obtained
 702:         # using them:

      (__pyx_v_errors[__pyx_v_i]) = (__pyx_v_h * ((((((__pyx_v_19geodesic_integrator_E1 * (__pyx_v_k1[__pyx_v_i])) + (__pyx_v_19geodesic_integrator_E3 * (__pyx_v_k3[__pyx_v_i]))) + (__pyx_v_19geodesic_integrator_E4 * (__pyx_v_k4[__pyx_v_i]))) + (__pyx_v_19geodesic_integrator_E5 * (__pyx_v_k5[__pyx_v_i]))) + (__pyx_v_19geodesic_integrator_E6 * (__pyx_v_k6[__pyx_v_i]))) + (__pyx_v_19geodesic_integrator_E7 * (__pyx_v_k7[__pyx_v_i]))));
    }

 706:                            E3 * k3[i] +
 707:                            E4 * k4[i] +
 708:                            E5 * k5[i] +
 709:                            E6 * k6[i] +
 710:                            E7 * k7[i])
 711: 
 712: 
 713: 
+714:         err = 0
    __pyx_v_err = 0.0;

 715: 
+716:         for i in range(5): # TODO: SYSTEM_SIZE
    for (__pyx_t_4 = 0; __pyx_t_4 < 5; __pyx_t_4+=1) {
      __pyx_v_i = __pyx_t_4;

 717:             # The local estimated error has to satisfy the following
 718:             # condition: |err[i]| < Atol[i] + Rtol*max(|y_0[i]|, |y_j[i]|)
 719:             # (see equation (4.10), [1]). The variable sk stores the right
 720:             # hand size of this inequality to use it as a scale in the local
 721:             # error computation this way we "normalize" the error and we can
 722:             # compare it against 1.
+723:             sk = atoli + rtoli*fmax(fabs(initCond[i]), fabs(y1[i]))
      __pyx_v_sk = (__pyx_v_atoli + (__pyx_v_rtoli * fmax(fabs((__pyx_v_initCond[__pyx_v_i])), fabs((__pyx_v_y1[__pyx_v_i])))));

 724: 
 725:             # Compute the square of the local estimated error (scaled with the
 726:             # previous factor), as the global error will be computed as in
 727:             # equation 4.11 ([1]): the square root of the mean of the squared
 728:             # local scaled errors.
+729:             sqr = (errors[i])/sk
      __pyx_v_sqr = ((__pyx_v_errors[__pyx_v_i]) / __pyx_v_sk);

+730:             errors[i] = sqr*sqr
      (__pyx_v_errors[__pyx_v_i]) = (__pyx_v_sqr * __pyx_v_sqr);

+731:             err += errors[i]
      __pyx_v_err = (__pyx_v_err + (__pyx_v_errors[__pyx_v_i]));
    }

 732: 
 733:         # The sum of the local squared errors in now in errors[0], but the
 734:         # global error is the square root of the mean of those local
 735:         # errors: we finish here the computation and store it in err.
+736:         err = sqrt(err / SYSTEM_SIZE)  # TODO: SYSTEM_SIZE
    __pyx_v_err = sqrt((__pyx_v_err / ((float)__pyx_v_19geodesic_integrator_SYSTEM_SIZE)));

 737: 
 738:         # For full information about the step size computation, please see
 739:         # equation (4.13) and its surroundings in [1] and the notes in
 740:         # Section IV.2 in [2].
 741:         # Mainly, the new step size is computed from the previous one and
 742:         # the current error in order to assure a high probability of
 743:         # having an acceptable error in the next step. Furthermore, safe
 744:         # factors and minimum/maximum factors are taken into account.
 745:         # The stabilization of the step size behaviour is done with the
 746:         # variable beta (expo1 depends only of beta), taking into account
 747:         # the previous accepted error
 748: 
 749:         # Stabilization computations:
+750:         fac11 = pow(err, expo1)
    __pyx_v_fac11 = pow(__pyx_v_err, __pyx_v_expo1);

+751:         fac = fac11 / pow(facold, beta)
    __pyx_v_fac = (((double)__pyx_v_fac11) / pow(__pyx_v_facold, __pyx_v_beta));

 752:         # We need the multiplying factor (always taking into account the
 753:         # safe factor) to be between fac1 and fac2 i.e., we require
 754:         # fac1 <= hnew/h <= fac2:
+755:         fac = fmax(fac2_inverse, fmin(fac1_inverse, fac * safeInv))
    __pyx_v_fac = fmax(__pyx_v_fac2_inverse, fmin(__pyx_v_fac1_inverse, (__pyx_v_fac * __pyx_v_safeInv)));

 756:         # New step final (but temporary) computation
+757:         hnew = h / fac
    __pyx_v_hnew = (__pyx_v_h / ((double)__pyx_v_fac));

 758: 
 759:         # Check whether the normalized error, err, is below or over 1.:
 760:         # REJECT STEP if err > 1.
 761: 
+762:         if err > 1.0:
    __pyx_t_2 = ((__pyx_v_err > 1.0) != 0);
    if (__pyx_t_2) {
/* … */
      goto __pyx_L25;
    }

 763: 
 764:             # Stabilization technique with the minimum and safe factors
 765:             #  when the step is rejected.
+766:             hnew = h / fmin(fac1_inverse, fac11 * safeInv)
      __pyx_v_hnew = (__pyx_v_h / fmin(__pyx_v_fac1_inverse, (__pyx_v_fac11 * __pyx_v_safeInv)));

+767:             reject = True
      __pyx_v_reject = 1;

 768: 
 769:         else:
 770: 
 771:             # Update old factor to new current error (upper bounded to 1e-4)
+772:             facold = fmax(err, 1.0e-4)
    /*else*/ {
      __pyx_v_facold = fmax(__pyx_v_err, 1.0e-4);

 773: 
 774:             # Advance current time!
+775:             x0 += h
      __pyx_v_x0 = (__pyx_v_x0 + __pyx_v_h);

 776: 
 777:             # Assure the new step size does not exceeds the provided
 778:             # bounds.
 779: 
+780:             if (fabs(hnew) > hmax):
      __pyx_t_2 = ((fabs(__pyx_v_hnew) > __pyx_v_hmax) != 0);
      if (__pyx_t_2) {
/* … */
      }

+781:                 hnew = integrationDirection * hmax
        __pyx_v_hnew = (__pyx_v_integrationDirection * __pyx_v_hmax);

 782: 
 783:             # If the previous step was rejected, take the minimum of the
 784:             # old and new step sizes
 785: 
+786:             if reject:
      __pyx_t_2 = (__pyx_v_reject != 0);
      if (__pyx_t_2) {
/* … */
      }

+787:                 hnew = integrationDirection * fmin(fabs(hnew), fabs(h))
        __pyx_v_hnew = (__pyx_v_integrationDirection * fmin(fabs(__pyx_v_hnew), fabs(__pyx_v_h)));

 788: 
 789:             # Necessary update for next steps: the local initCond variable holds
 790:             # the current initial condition (now the computed solution)
 791: 
+792:             for i in range(5): # TODO: SYSTEM_SIZE
      for (__pyx_t_4 = 0; __pyx_t_4 < 5; __pyx_t_4+=1) {
        __pyx_v_i = __pyx_t_4;

+793:                 initCond[i] = y1[i]
        (__pyx_v_initCond[__pyx_v_i]) = (__pyx_v_y1[__pyx_v_i]);
      }

 794: 
 795:             # This step was accepted, so it was not rejected, so reject is
 796:             # false. SCIENCE.
 797: 
+798:             reject = False
      __pyx_v_reject = 0;
    }
    __pyx_L25:;

 799: 
 800: 
 801:         # Final step size update!
 802: 
+803:         h = hnew
    __pyx_v_h = __pyx_v_hnew;
  }

 804: 
 805:     # END WHILE LOOP
 806: 
 807:     # Update the user's h, facold and x0 
 808: 
+809:     hOrig[0] = h
  (__pyx_v_hOrig[0]) = __pyx_v_h;

+810:     globalFacold[0] = facold
  (__pyx_v_globalFacold[0]) = __pyx_v_facold;

+811:     globalX0[0] = x0
  (__pyx_v_globalX0[0]) = __pyx_v_x0;

 812:
